hints.content:
We can use the related multiplication equation to help us.

$\goldE{40} \div \blueE{7} = \maroonE{{?}}$

So, $\blueE{7} \times \maroonE{{?}}= \goldE{40}$.

No whole number value of $\maroonE{{?}}$ makes the equation exactly true. 

Let's try different values of $\maroonE{?}$ to get close to a product of $\goldE{40}$.

$\begin{align}
\blueE{7} \times \maroonE{4} &= 28 \\\\
\blueE{7} \times \maroonE{5} &= 35 \\\\
\blueE{7} \times \maroonE{6} &= 42
\end{align}$

Which two values of $\maroonE{?}$ get us the closest to $\goldE{40}$?
The total $\goldE{40}$ is between $35$ and $42$, so $\maroonE{?}$ is between $\maroonE{5}$ and $\maroonE{6}$.

The point that represents $\goldE{40} \div \blueE{7}$ is between $\maroonE{5}$ and $\maroonE{6}$.

[[☃ image 1]]

[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
[[☃ image 1]]

It takes more than $\maroonE{5}$ rows of $\blueE{7}$, but less than $\maroonE{6}$ full rows of $\blueE{7}$ to equal $\goldE{40}$.
options.showPrompt: Please show me a picture of what this means.

options.alt: An array of 40 circles arranged in 5 rows of 7 circles each and 1 row with 5 circles.
A number line from 5 to 10, with a tick every 1 unit. A point is labeled between the tick mark labeled 5 and the tick mark labeled 6. !

question.content:
The following quotient is between two whole numbers.

$40 \div 7$

**Which point on the number line could represent the quotient?**

[[☃ radio 1]]
